00001 ## @mainpage Poisson Disk Sampling
00002 ##
00003 ## Contains functions for Poisson disk sampling, and the classes and functions
00004 ## that support it. The code can be downloaded from http://www.luma.co.za/labs/2008/02/27/poisson-disk-sampling.
00005 ##

00038 ##@brief Returns a random integer in the range [0, n-1] inclusive.
00039 def rand(n):
00040         return randint(0, n - 1)
00041 
00042 ##@brief The square of the distance between the given points
00043 def sqr_dist((x0, y0), (x1, y1)):
00044         return (x1 - x0)*(x1 - x0) + (y1 - y0)*(y1 - y0)
00045 
00046 ##@brief The square of the distance between the given points
00047 def sqr_dist_3d((x0, y0, z0), (x1, y1, z1)):
00048         return (x1 - x0)*(x1 - x0) + (y1 - y0)*(y1 - y0) + (z1 - z0)*(z1 - z0) 
00049 
00050 
00051 ## @brief Gives a Poisson sample of points of a rectangle.
00052 ##
00053 # @param width
00054 #               The width of the rectangle to sample
00055 # @param height
00056 #               The height of the rectangle to sample
00057 # @param r
00058 #               The mimum distance between points, in terms of 
00059 #               rectangle units. For example, in a 10 by 10 grid, a mimum distance of 
00060 #               10 will probably only give you one sample point.
00061 # @param k
00062 #               The algorithm generates k points around points already 
00063 #               in the sample, and then check if they are not too close
00064 #               to other points. Typically, k = 30 is sufficient. The larger 
00065 #               k is, the slower th algorithm, but the more sample points
00066 #               are produced.
00067 # @return A list of tuples representing x, y coordinates of
00068 #               of the sample points. The coordinates are not necesarily
00069 #               integers, so that the can be more accurately scaled to be
00070 #               used on larger rectangles.
00071 def sample_poisson_uniform(width, height, r, k):
00072         #Convert rectangle (the one to be sampled) coordinates to 
00073         # coordinates in the grid.
00074         def grid_coordinates((x, y)):
00075                 return (int(x*inv_cell_size), int(y*inv_cell_size))
00076         
00077         # Puts a sample point in all the algorithm's relevant containers.
00078         def put_point(p):
00079                 process_list.push(p)
00080                 sample_points.append(p)  
00081                 grid[grid_coordinates(p)] = p
00082 
00083         # Generates a point randomly selected around
00084         # the given point, between r and 2*r units away.
00085         def generate_random_around((x, y), r):
00086                 rr = uniform(r, 2*r)
00087                 rt = uniform(0, 2*pi)
00088                 
00089                 return rr*sin(rt) + x, rr*cos(rt) + y
00090                 
00091         # Is the given point in the rectangle to be sampled?
00092         def in_rectangle((x, y)):
00093                 return 0 <= x < width and 0 <= y < height
00094                 
00095         def in_neighbourhood(p):
00096                 gp = gx, gy = grid_coordinates(p)
00097                 
00098                 if grid[gp]: return True
00099                 
00100                 for cell in grid.square_iter(gp, 2):
00101                         if cell and sqr_dist(cell, p) <= r_sqr:
00102                                 return True
00103                 return False
00104 
00105         #Create the grid
00106         cell_size = r/sqrt(2)
00107         inv_cell_size = 1 / cell_size   
00108         r_sqr = r*r
00109         
00110         grid = Grid2D((int(ceil(width/cell_size)),
00111                 int(ceil(height/cell_size))))
00112                 
00113         process_list = RandomQueue()
00114         sample_points = []      
00115         
00116         #generate the first point
00117         put_point((rand(width), rand(height)))
00118         
00119         #generate other points from points in queue.
00120         while not process_list.empty():
00121                 p = process_list.pop()
00122                 
00123                 for i in range(k):
00124                         q = generate_random_around(p, r)
00125                         if in_rectangle(q) and not in_neighbourhood(q):
00126                                         put_point(q)
00127         
00128         return sample_points
00129         
00130 ##@brief Gives a Poisson sample of points of a rectangle with an arbitrary distance function between points.
00131 ##
00132 # @param width
00133 #               The width of the rectangle to sample
00134 # @param height
00135 #               The height of the rectangle to sample
00136 # @param r_grid
00137 #               r_grid[x, y] is the mimum distance between points around x, y, in terms of 
00138 #               rectangle units. 
00139 # @param k
00140 #               The algorithm generates k points around points already 
00141 #               in the sample, and then check if they are not too close
00142 #               to other points. Typically, k = 30 is sufficient. The larger 
00143 #               k is, the slower th algorithm, but the more sample points
00144 #               are produced.
00145 # @return A list of tuples representing x, y coordinates of
00146 #               of the sample points. The coordinates are not necesarily
00147 #               integers, so that the can be more accurately scaled to be
00148 #               used on larger rectangles.
00149 def sample_poisson(width, height, r_grid, k):   
00150         #Convert rectangle (the one to be sampled) coordinates to 
00151         # coordinates in the grid.
00152         def grid_coordinates((x, y)):
00153                 return (int(x*inv_cell_size), int(y*inv_cell_size))
00154         
00155         # Puts a sample point in all the algorithm's relevant containers.
00156         def put_point(p):
00157                 process_list.push(p)
00158                 sample_points.append(p)  
00159                 grid[grid_coordinates(p)].append(p)
00160 
00161         # Generates a point randomly selected around
00162         # the given point, between r and 2*r units away.
00163         def generate_random_around((x, y), r):
00164                 rr = uniform(r, 2*r)
00165                 rt = uniform(0, 2*pi)
00166                 
00167                 return rr*sin(rt) + x, rr*cos(rt) + y
00168                 
00169         # Is the given point in the rectangle to be sampled?
00170         def in_rectangle((x, y)):
00171                 return 0 <= x < width and 0 <= y < height
00172         
00173         def in_neighbourhood(p, r):
00174                 gp = grid_coordinates(p)
00175                 r_sqr = r*r
00176                 
00177                 for cell in grid.square_iter(gp, 2):
00178                         for q in cell:
00179                                 if sqr_dist(q, p) <= r_sqr:
00180                                         return True
00181                 return False
00182 
00183         r_min, r_max = r_grid.min_max()
00184         
00185         #Create the grid
00186         cell_size = r_max/sqrt(2)
00187         inv_cell_size = 1 / cell_size   
00188         r_max_sqr = r_max*r_max
00189         
00190         grid = ListGrid2D(int_point_2d((ceil(width/cell_size),
00191                 ceil(height/cell_size))))
00192                 
00193         process_list = RandomQueue()
00194         sample_points = []      
00195         
00196         #generate the first point
00197         put_point((rand(width), rand(height)))
00198         
00199         #generate other points from points in queue.
00200         while not process_list.empty():
00201                 p = process_list.pop()
00202                 r = r_grid[int_point_2d(p)]
00203                 
00204                 for i in range(k):                     
00205                         q = generate_random_around(p, r)
00206                         if in_rectangle(q) and not in_neighbourhood(q, r):
00207                                         put_point(q)
00208         
00209         return sample_points
00210 
00211 ##@brief Gives a Poisson sample of points of a box (3D rectangle).
00212 ##
00213 # @param width
00214 #               The width of the box to sample
00215 # @param height
00216 #               The height of the box to sample
00217 # @param depth
00218 #               The depth of the box to sample.  
00219 # @param r_grid
00220 #               r_grid[x, y, z] is the mimum distance between points around x, y, z, in terms of 
00221 #               rectangle units. 
00222 # @param k
00223 #               The algorithm generates k points around points already 
00224 #               in the sample, and then check if they are not too close
00225 #               to other points. Typically, k = 30 is sufficient. The larger 
00226 #               k is, the slower th algorithm, but the more sample points
00227 #               are produced.
00228 # @return A list of tuples representing x, y coordinates of
00229 #               of the sample points. The coordinates are not necesarily
00230 #               integers, so that the can be more accurately scaled to be
00231 #               used on larger rectangles.
00232 def sample_poisson_3d(width, height, depth, r_grid, k): 
00233         #Convert rectangle (the one to be sampled) coordinates to 
00234         # coordinates in the grid.
00235         def grid_coordinates((x, y, z)):
00236                 return int_point_3d((x*inv_cell_size, y*inv_cell_size, z*inv_cell_size))
00237         
00238         # Puts a sample point in all the algorithm's relevant containers.
00239         def put_point(p):
00240                 process_list.push(p)
00241                 sample_points.append(p)
00242                 grid[grid_coordinates(p)].append(p)
00243 
00244         # Generates a point randomly selected around
00245         # the given point, between r and 2*r units away.
00246         def generate_random_around((x, y, z), r):
00247                 rr = uniform(r, 2*r)            
00248                 rs = uniform(0, 2*pi)
00249                 rt = uniform(0, 2*pi)           
00250                 
00251                 return rr*sin(rs)*cos(rt) + x, rr*sin(rs)*sin(rt) + y, rr*cos(rs) + z
00252                 
00253         # Is the given point in the rectangle to be sampled?
00254         def in_rectangle((x, y, z)):
00255                 return 0 <= x < width and 0 <= y < height and 0 <= z < depth
00256         
00257         def in_neighbourhood(p, r):
00258                 gp = grid_coordinates(p)
00259                 r_sqr = r*r
00260                 
00261                 for cell in grid.square_iter(gp, 2):
00262                         for q in cell:
00263                                 if sqr_dist_3d(q, p) <= r_sqr:
00264                                         return True
00265                 return False
00266 
00267         r_min, r_max = r_grid.min_max()
00268         
00269         #Create the grid
00270         cell_size = r_max/sqrt(2)
00271         inv_cell_size = 1 / cell_size   
00272         r_max_sqr = r_max*r_max
00273         
00274         grid = ListGrid3D((
00275                 int(ceil(width/cell_size)),
00276                 int(ceil(height/cell_size)),
00277                 int(ceil(depth/cell_size))))
00278                 
00279         process_list = RandomQueue()
00280         sample_points = []      
00281         
00282         #generate the first point
00283         put_point((rand(width), rand(height), rand(depth)))
00284         
00285         #generate other points from points in queue.
00286         while not process_list.empty():
00287                 p = process_list.pop()
00288                 r = r_grid[int_point_3d(p)]
00289 
00290                 for i in range(k):                     
00291                         q = generate_random_around(p, r)
00292                         if in_rectangle(q) and not in_neighbourhood(q, r):
00293                                         put_point(q)
00294         
00295         return sample_points
